race.name: Pony Xpress
race.tagline: Remote southern Colorado gravel through Sangre de Cristo mining country.

climate.description: High altitude with variable conditions. Wind and sun exposure. 70% of course sheltered by trees and canyons.

terrain.primary: Colorado high desert and foothills gravel
terrain.surface: 96% gravel county roads, 4% blacktop. Fine gravel suitable for lighter tires. Rolling foothills, forests, and open plains.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Part of Colorado Gravel Grinder Championships series. Genuine altitude and climbing in remote setting but small field and limited national recognition.

biased_opinion.summary: Pony Xpress is a remote gravel race in southern Colorado's Sangre de Cristo Mountains, part of the Colorado Gravel Grinder Championships series. The 85K distance carries the USACycling Colorado State Gravel Grinder Championship designation. The course rolls through historic mining areas, past the Ludlow Memorial, with Fisher Peak views and genuine altitude from 6,000 to 8,800 feet. It's well-organized with four distance options (160K, 85K, 48K, 85K e-bike) but draws a regional field to a remote location.
strengths: Part of Colorado Gravel Grinder Championships series
Historic mining country and Ludlow Memorial
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid Colorado gravel grinder in genuinely remote mining country with real altitude. Worth it for Colorado cyclists who want a remote adventure with championship-series organization. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers, but the terrain and history deliver.

final_verdict.one_liner: Remote southern Colorado gravel through Sangre de Cristo mining country at altitude.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Colorado and want a remote gravel adventure through mining history at altitude—yes, it's a well-organized event with serious terrain. If you're from out of state—there are more accessible events with deeper fields.
final_verdict.alternatives: For bigger Colorado events: SBT GRVL, Steamboat Gravel. For similar remote Colorado gravel: Ned Gravel, Grit & Gravel. For championship-level gravel: Unbound, BWR.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Cokedale has minimal lodging. Trinidad (30 min) has more options. Fairgrounds camping $25/night.
logistics.food: Tiny town with minimal dining. Trinidad has restaurants. Bring race nutrition.
logistics.packet_pickup: Saturday before at Tarantula Cycles, 200 E. Main St, Trinidad. Race-day pickup 7-8:30 AM at start.

history.origin_story: Annual gravel event in southern Colorado, part of the Colorado Gravel Grinder Championships series. Inspired by the 1860s Pony Express riders who crossed remote, desolate regions.
history.reputation: Remote Colorado gravel grinder with genuine altitude and mining-country character.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 100 miles of remote southern Colorado gravel at altitude through mining country.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Remote gravel through Sangre de Cristo Mountains with 7,300 feet of climbing.

logistics.explanation: Packet pickup split between Trinidad on Saturday and race-day pickup ending at 8:30 AM for a 9 AM start. Whitney Allison noted that 'newly and deeply graded roads' made times slower in 2022, suggesting inconsistent course preparation. Remote Las Animas County location means limited services and the 2025 race already got postponed from April to May.

length.explanation: 100 miles with 7,300 feet of climbing hits serious gravel distance territory. Whitney Allison rode 'the next ~92 miles almost entirely alone, passing dozens of age groupers' after the opening 13-mile climb separated the field. The double-lap 85K format provides bailout options but the full distance demands self-reliance in remote terrain. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Holly Geilman puts it: "Miles 41-50.1 were more focused but full of more mountain and desert views. Ok, let's get this done! When I passed the finish line the first time, another checkpoint, I kept running to complete the sh..."

technicality.explanation: Course organizers recommend 'lighter tires can be run' on these 'fine gravel' county roads, suggesting manageable surfaces. However, Whitney Allison found that 'the higher elevation parts of the course were quite technical' in 2022 conditions. Road bikes can finish but gravel or mountain bikes handle the 'endless curvy areas' better. Less technical than The Mid South. As Surface Quality puts it: "These roads are fine gravel, so lighter tires can be run. Rain or snow makes the conditions fast."

elevation.explanation: 4,500 feet of climbing over 100 miles with a range from 6,000 to 8,800 feet elevation. That's vertical in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains. Not crushing, but enough to separate the climbers from the pretenders. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: 50°F start to 75°F midday in May is nearly perfect gravel weather. Southern Colorado location reduces snow risk, and 70% tree/canyon shelter protects from wind. Hard to complain about those conditions. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL. As Surface Quality puts it: "These roads are fine gravel, so lighter tires can be run. Rain or snow makes the conditions fast."

altitude.explanation: Starting at 6,000 feet and maxing out at 8,800 feet will humble sea-level riders quickly. That's altitude that affects performance and requires acclimatization. The thin air doesn't care about your FTP. Higher altitude racing, comparable to SBT GRVL.

adventure.explanation: Race organizers warn that 'portions of the course have no mobile phone reception' and emphasize that 'you cannot ride till your too tired and then pull over and expect someone to ferry you home.' The remote Las Animas County roads require GPS navigation and self-reliance, with no support crews allowed on course.

prestige.explanation: Part of the Colorado Gravel Grinder Championships series, but nobody's talking about it online. Zero notable past winners or pro field depth mentioned anywhere. It's inspired by the 1860s Pony Express which sounds cool until you realize that's just marketing fluff for a remote Colorado county road ride.

race_quality.explanation: 90% gravel county roads through Las Animas County with proper feed stations and organization. The course design makes sense - 160K is two laps of 85K, clean distance options. But it's essentially a well-marked county road tour, not some epic gravel masterpiece.

experience.explanation: Rolling through wooded forests and mining areas with Fisher Peak views, 70% sheltered from wind by trees and canyons. The Ludlow Memorial adds actual historical weight beyond the Pony Express branding. Limited cell service and remote terrain means you better know what you're doing out there.

community.explanation: Small-town Colorado vibe in Cokedale, packet pickup at Tarantula Cycles in Trinidad. It's the kind of race where locals show up and ride, then go home - which isn't necessarily bad, just quiet.

field_depth.explanation: Limited entries noted but no actual field sizes or competitive depth mentioned. Zero notable riders or race reports found. The pro/open categories start just 5 minutes apart, which tells you everything about the 'depth' of competition. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Whitney Allison puts it: "I was the only 'pro class' woman and there were 16 men in the same 'pro class' field with a separate start."

value.explanation: $129.95 for the 160K gets you three feed stations, lunch, awards, and remote mountain terrain access. The fairgrounds camping option adds $25 per night with basic facilities. Standard Colorado gravel pricing for a well-supported event, though the small fields suggest riders are finding better value elsewhere.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $80-120. Trinidad, Colorado isn't a destination resort, so lodging and food should be reasonable. No airport mentioned means you're driving, probably from Denver. Middle-of-nowhere location keeps costs down once you're there. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.
